frequent_forms.usage_notes: Essential for expressing likes. The verb agrees with the item being liked ('el café'), not the person.
Used when the subject is 'tú' (you), typically to express personal (often romantic) interest in someone.
Very common for expressing opinions ('Me parece que...') or making observations ('Parece que va a llover').
Used for self-description or comparison, meaning 'I seem' or 'I look like'.
Key for indicating your origin or current movement, as in 'Vengo del trabajo' (I'm coming from work).
The simple past tense (preterite) form. Essential for narrating past events.
Used to express continuation, meaning 'I continue' or 'I'm still' doing something (e.g., 'Sigo aquí' - I'm still here).
The present progressive form, emphasizing an action in progress right now.
Means 'I find'. Also used reflexively ('me encuentro') to describe one's state: 'Me encuentro mal' (I feel sick).
The simple past (preterite) form, 'I found'. Used for completed actions in the past.
A versatile verb. 'Paso por...' means 'I pass by...'. Can also mean 'I spend (time)' as in 'Paso tiempo con amigos'.
Simple past (preterite). Often used to talk about how you spent your time: 'Lo pasé bien' (I had a good time).
Fundamental for the concept of 'giving'. Used in many common phrases and transactions.
Simple past (preterite) of 'dar'. Crucial for recounting past actions of giving or taking ('di un paseo' - I took a walk).
Used when stating that you are asking a question. Differentiated from 'pedir' (to ask for/request).
The 'tú' form, essential for engaging in conversation and asking if the other person has a question.
The counterpart to 'preguntar' (to ask); means 'I answer' or 'I respond'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I answered'.
One of the most critical survival verbs for expressing needs, from asking for the bathroom to needing help.
Essential for asking about another person's needs, such as in the common phrase '¿Necesitas ayuda?' (Do you need help?).
A highly versatile verb meaning 'to take' (transport, an object) or 'to have' a drink or meal.
Simple past (preterite) form, used to talk about what you took, ate, or drank.
Essential for ordering food/drinks and requesting items. Different from 'preguntar' (to ask a question).
The 'tú' form, used for asking what someone else is ordering or requesting.
Common verb meaning 'to receive' or 'to get'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I received'.
Extremely useful for travelers and beginners, as in 'Busco el baño' (I'm looking for the bathroom).
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I looked for'. Note the spelling change from 'c' to 'qu' to maintain the sound.
Dual meaning verb: 'to wait for' and 'to hope'. Context determines the meaning.
The 'tú' form, common for asking if someone is waiting.
A fundamental verb for talking about travel and tourism.
Simple past (preterite), used to describe past trips.
Basic vocabulary for daily routines and hobbies, meaning 'I cook'.
Emphasizes the action of cooking happening at this very moment.
A common verb for household chores and daily routines, meaning 'I clean'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I cleaned'.
Means 'I paint', used for both artistic painting and house painting.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I painted'.
Means 'he/she/it builds'. Note the vowel change in the stem.
The passive voice form, common on signs, meaning 'is being built'.
A useful verb meaning 'I change', applicable to many contexts (clothes, plans, money).
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I changed'.
Means 'I begin' or 'I start'. A common stem-changing verb (e -> ie).
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I started'. Note the spelling change (z -> c).
The counterpart to 'empezar', meaning 'I finish' or 'I end'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I finished'.
Irregular verb meaning 'I hear'. Different from 'escuchar' (to listen to).
Progressive form, 'I am hearing'. Note the spelling change (i -> y).
Means 'I smile'. Note the accent mark on the 'i'.
The 'tú' form, 'you smile'.
Basic emotion verb, meaning 'I cry'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I cried'.
Means 'I laugh'. Often used reflexively ('me río'). Note the accent mark.
Simple past (preterite) reflexive form, 'I laughed'.
Dual meaning verb: 'to count' and 'to tell' (a story). A stem-changing verb (o -> ue).
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I counted' or 'I told'.
Means 'I remember'. A common stem-changing verb (o -> ue).
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I remembered'.
Means 'I forget'. Often used reflexively ('se me olvida') to mean 'it slipped my mind'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I forgot'.
Means 'I choose' or 'I elect'. Note the spelling change (g -> j) in the 'yo' form.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I chose'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I sit down'. A common stem-changing verb (e -> ie).
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I sat down'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I get up'. A core verb for describing daily routines.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I got up'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I go to bed'. A common stem-changing verb (o -> ue).
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I went to bed'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I take a shower'. Part of the daily routine vocabulary.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I took a shower'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I get dressed'. A stem-changing verb (e -> i).
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I got dressed'.
Reflexive verb with multiple meanings, most commonly 'to stay' or 'to remain'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I stayed'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I have fun'. A stem-changing verb (e -> ie).
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I had fun'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I get angry'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I got angry'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I am glad' or 'I am happy' (about something).
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I was glad'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I get tired'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I got tired'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I am getting married'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'he/she got married'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I fall in love'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I fell in love'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I worry'.
The 'tú' form, 'you worry'.
Reflexive verb meaning 'I remember'. It is a synonym for 'recordar'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I remembered'.
Works like 'gustar'. It means 'to be lacking' or 'to be missing'. 'Me falta' means 'I am missing...'.
Plural form used when multiple items are lacking or to express remaining time.
Works like 'gustar'. 'Me interesa' means 'I am interested in...'.
The plural form, used when you are interested in multiple things.
Essential for health issues. Works like 'gustar'. 'Me duele...' means 'My... hurts'.
The plural form, used when more than one thing hurts. 'Me duelen...' means 'My... (plural) hurt'.
Works like 'gustar'. 'Me importa' means '... is important to me' or 'I care about...'. 'No importa' is a key phrase for 'It doesn't matter'.
Used to express that a person matters to you: 'You are important to me'.
Means 'to happen' or 'to occur'. Often used like 'pasar'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'it happened'.
Absolutely essential for introductions: stating your name, nationality, profession, and inherent characteristics.
The most common form of 'ser'. Used to describe nearly everything: people, things, time ('es la una'), characteristics, etc.
The foundation of the most common greeting, '¿Cómo estás?'. Also used for location ('¿Dónde estás?').
Essential for expressing your location ('estoy en casa'), feelings ('estoy bien'), and forming the present progressive ('estoy hablando').
Essential for expressing possession, age ('tengo 30 años'), physical states ('tengo hambre'), and obligation ('tengo que trabajar').
Used constantly to talk about what other people or things have. '¿Tiene baño?' is a critical travel question.
Extremely versatile. Used for weather ('hace sol'), time expressions ('hace dos años'), and describing what someone else does.
The 'yo' preterite form ('I did/made'), key for narrating past personal actions.
Crucial for expressing movement ('voy al mercado') and is the base for the most common future construction, 'ir a + infinitive' ('voy a comer').
Used for asking about others' plans ('¿Vas a la fiesta?') and movement ('¿Adónde vas?').
Essential for asking for permission ('¿Puedo entrar?'), stating ability, and ordering politely ('¿Me puede traer...?').
Crucial for making requests ('¿Puedes ayudarme?') and asking about someone's ability.
'I say' or 'I tell'. Key for reporting speech or expressing your opinion.
'He/she says'. Very common for reporting what others have said.
'I see'. Used for literal sight and for understanding ('Veo lo que quieres decir').
The 'yo' preterite form ('I saw'), fundamental for talking about past events.
'I know'. Crucial for expressing knowledge of facts or skills. 'No sé' (I don't know) is a vital survival phrase.
'You know'. Essential for asking for information ('¿Sabes dónde está el baño?').
One of the most important verbs for a beginner, used to express wants and desires ('Quiero un café').
Essential for making invitations and asking others what they want ('¿Quieres ir al cine?').
Basic verb for daily routines, 'I eat'.
The 'yo' preterite form ('I ate'), necessary for discussing past meals.
Basic verb for daily routines, 'I drink'.
The 'tú' form, 'you drink'.
Important for personal information, 'I live'.
'He/she lives'. Used for asking or talking about where others live.
Critical for language learners ('Hablo un poco de español').
Essential for asking others about their language abilities ('¿Hablas inglés?').
'I write'. A fundamental communication verb.
The 'yo' preterite form ('I wrote').
'I read'. Common verb for hobbies and activities.
Present progressive, emphasizes the action of reading happening now.
'I sleep'. A stem-changing verb (o->ue) for daily routines.
The 'yo' preterite form ('I slept').
'I work'. Important for personal introductions.
'You work'. Used in common conversational questions like '¿Dónde trabajas?'.
'I study'. Key for students and language learners.
'You study'. Used for the common question '¿Qué estudias?' (What do you study?).
'I learn'. Very relevant for language students.
Present progressive, emphasizes the ongoing process of learning.
Crucial for communication. 'No entiendo' (I don't understand) is a key survival phrase. A stem-changing verb (e->ie).
Important for checking comprehension: '¿Entiendes?' (Do you understand?).
'I know' (am familiar with) a person, place, or thing. It's distinct from 'saber', which is for facts or skills. The 'yo' form is irregular ('-zco').
'You know' (are familiar with). Key for asking questions like '¿Conoces a María?' (Do you know Maria?).

frequent_forms.example: Pienso que es una buena idea.
frequent_forms.usage_notes: 'I think'. A fundamental verb for expressing opinions ('Pienso que...') and plans ('Pienso ir...'). It's a common stem-changing verb (e -> ie).
'You think'. Used in the very common question '¿Qué piensas?' (What do you think?).
Extremely important. The base for 'Lo siento' (I'm sorry). Also used for physical sensations: 'Siento frío' (I feel cold).
Essential reflexive form for expressing emotions or physical states: 'Me siento bien/mal/cansado' (I feel good/bad/tired).
'I listen to'. Refers to the intentional act of listening, as opposed to 'oír' (to hear).
Present progressive form, 'I am listening to', emphasizing the action is happening at this moment.
'I watch' or 'I look at'. A very common verb for describing activities.
Present progressive, 'I am watching/looking at', to describe an action in progress.
Has a dual meaning: 'to touch' and 'to play' a musical instrument.
Simple past (preterite) form. Note the spelling change (c -> qu) to preserve the hard 'k' sound.
'I sing'. A regular -ar verb, often used as a model for conjugation patterns.
Present progressive form, 'I am singing'.
'I dance'. Another regular -ar verb, common for talking about hobbies and social activities.
'You dance'. Useful for asking questions about social activities.
'I run'. A regular -er verb, useful for talking about exercise and daily activities.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I ran'.
'I walk'. A fundamental verb for movement and daily routines.
Present progressive form, 'I am walking'.
'I swim'. A common verb for sports and hobbies.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I swam'.
'I play' (a sport or a game). A common stem-changing verb (u -> ue).
'You play'. Common for asking about sports/hobbies ('¿Juegas al fútbol?').
Simple past (preterite) 3rd person, 'he/she/it won'. Common in sports contexts.
Has a dual meaning: 'I win' or 'I earn' (money).
Simple past (preterite), 'I lost'. Useful for common situations like losing keys.
'I lose'. A common stem-changing verb (e -> ie).
'I open'. A basic action verb.

frequent_forms.example: La tienda se abre a las 9.
frequent_forms.usage_notes: Passive form, 'it opens'. Often seen on signs for store hours.
'I close'. A common stem-changing verb (e -> ie).
Passive form, 'it closes'. Used for store hours ('Se cierra a las 5').
'I put' or 'I place'. An irregular 'yo' form verb (-go verb) used in many daily tasks.
Reflexive form, 'I put on' (clothing) or 'I become' (an emotion, e.g., 'me pongo triste').
'I take out' or 'I get'. A versatile verb (e.g., 'saco la basura', 'saco buenas notas').
Simple past (preterite), 'I took out'. Note the spelling change (c -> qu).
'I bring'. An irregular 'yo' form (-igo verb). Contrasts with 'llevar' (to take/carry away).
Simple past (preterite), 'I brought'. A highly irregular preterite stem.
A very versatile verb: 'I wear' (clothing), 'I carry' (an object), or 'I take' (someone somewhere).
Simple past (preterite), 'I wore', 'I carried', 'I took'.
'I leave' (something behind) or 'I allow'. Different from 'salir' (to leave a place).
Simple past (preterite), 'I left' (something).
'I return' or 'I come back'. A common stem-changing verb (o -> ue).
Simple past (preterite), 'I returned'.
'I leave' or 'I go out'. An irregular 'yo' form (-go verb).
'You leave/go out'. Used for asking about plans ('¿Sales esta noche?').
'I enter'. The opposite of 'salir'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I entered'.
'I meet up with' or 'I arrange to meet'. Without the reflexive 'me', it's about making plans.
Critical for locations ('¿Dónde queda...?') and talking about what is remaining ('Queda un poco de café').
'I arrive'. A fundamental verb for travel and appointments.
Simple past (preterite), 'I arrived'. Note the spelling change (g -> gu).
'I buy'. An essential verb for shopping and commerce.
Simple past (preterite), 'I bought'.
'He/she sells'. Commonly seen on signs 'Se vende' (For sale).
'I sell'. The opposite of 'comprar'.
'I help'. A very common social interaction verb.
Most useful for asking if someone needs help ('¿Necesitas ayuda?') and in the imperative form '¡Ayuda!' (Help!).
A synonym for 'empezar', 'I begin/start'. A stem-changing verb (e -> ie).
Simple past (preterite), 'I began'. Note the spelling change (z -> c).
'I believe'. Used frequently to express opinions, e.g., 'Creo que sí/no' (I think so/not).
'You believe'. Used for asking for opinions.
'I try'. A useful verb typically followed by an infinitive ('Intento aprender').
Simple past (preterite), 'I tried'.
'I achieve' or 'I manage to'. A stronger, more successful version of 'intentar'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I achieved'.
'I get' or 'I obtain'. An irregular 'yo' form (gu -> g) and stem-changing (e -> i).
Simple past (preterite), 'I got'.
'I maintain' or 'I keep'. Follows the pattern of 'tener' with an irregular 'yo' form (-tengo).
Simple past (preterite), 'I maintained'. Follows the irregular preterite pattern of 'tener'.
'I forgive'. Less common than its imperative form.
Essential imperative form. A very common way to say 'excuse me' or 'pardon me' to get someone's attention.
'I accept'. Used for invitations, offers, terms, etc.
'You accept'.
'I reject'. The opposite of 'aceptar'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I rejected'. Note spelling change (z -> c).
'I explain'. A key verb for communication.
Simple past (preterite), 'I explained'. Note spelling change (c -> qu).
'I show'. A stem-changing verb (o -> ue).
Simple past (preterite), 'I showed'.
Has a dual meaning: 'I teach' and 'I show'. A synonym of 'mostrar'.
'You teach' or 'you show'.
Reflexive form of 'aprender', meaning 'to learn by heart' or 'to memorize'.
Simple past (preterite) form, 'I memorized'.
'I prepare' or 'I make' (food, plans, etc.).
Present progressive form, 'I am preparing'.
'I fix', 'I arrange', or 'I tidy up'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I fixed'.
'I wash'. Common verb for chores.
Simple past (preterite), 'I washed'.
'I dry'. Often used reflexively, 'me seco'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I dried'. Note spelling change (c -> qu).
'I cut'. Basic action verb.
Simple past (preterite), 'I cut'.
'I break'. Also used for ending relationships ('romper con alguien').
Simple past (preterite), 'I broke'.
'I fall'. An irregular 'yo' form (-igo verb).
Simple past (preterite), 'I fell'.
'I go up', 'I climb', or 'I get on' (a vehicle).
Simple past (preterite), 'I went up'.
'I go down', 'I get off' (a vehicle), or 'I download'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I went down'.
'I correct'. Irregular 'yo' form (g -> j) and stem-changing (e -> i).
Simple past (preterite), 'I corrected'.
'I invite'. Common social verb.
'You invite'.
'I visit'. Used for both people and places.
Simple past (preterite), 'I visited'.
'I rest'. Common verb for daily routines.
Present progressive, 'I am resting'.
'I practice'. Used for sports, hobbies, and skills.
Simple past (preterite), 'I practiced'. Note spelling change (c -> qu).
'I compete'. A stem-changing verb (e -> i).
Simple past (preterite), 'I competed'.
'I share'. A key social verb.
Simple past (preterite), 'I shared'.
'I discuss'. Can also mean 'I argue' depending on context.
Simple past (preterite), 'I discussed' or 'I argued'.
'I approve' or 'I pass' (an exam). A stem-changing verb (o -> ue).
Simple past (preterite), 'I passed'.
'I fail' (an exam). The opposite of 'aprobar'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I failed'.
'I attend'. A false friend; it does not mean 'to assist'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I attended'.
'I participate'. Used with 'en' ('participar en').
Simple past (preterite), 'I participated'.
'I direct', 'I manage', or 'I lead'. Irregular 'yo' form (g -> j).
'He/she directs'.
'I protect'. Irregular 'yo' form (g -> j).
Simple past (preterite), 'I protected'.
'I resolve' or 'I solve'. A stem-changing verb (o -> ue).
Simple past (preterite), 'I solved'.
'I promise'. A common social commitment verb.
Simple past (preterite), 'I promised'.
'I fulfill' or 'I carry out'. Also used for birthdays: 'cumplir años' (to have a birthday).
Simple past (preterite), 'I fulfilled' or 'I turned' (an age).
'It surprises'. Often used like 'gustar': 'Me sorprende que...' (It surprises me that...).
Simple past (preterite), 'I surprised'.
'It attracts'. Follows the pattern of 'traer' and is often used like 'gustar'.
'You attract'. Used to express personal attraction.
'I confuse' or 'I mix up'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I confused'.
'I mix'. Common verb in cooking and other contexts.
Simple past (preterite), 'I mixed'.
'I separate'. A basic action verb.
Simple past (preterite), 'I separated'.
'I unite' or 'I join'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I united'.
'I turn off' (lights, devices).
Simple past (preterite), 'I turned off'. Note spelling change (g -> gu).
'I turn on'. The opposite of 'apagar'. A stem-changing verb (e -> ie).
Simple past (preterite), 'I turned on'.
Essential for talking about whether something works or not. 'No funciona' is a critical phrase for any traveler.
Simple past (preterite), 'it worked'.
'It exists'. Primarily used in the third person.
'They exist'. Plural form of 'existe'.
'I take advantage of'. Used for opportunities, time, etc.
Simple past (preterite), 'I took advantage of'.
'I imagine'. Often used as 'Me imagino que...' (I imagine that...).
A very common imperative form used as an interjection meaning 'Imagine that!' or 'Just think!'.
'I design'. Used in creative and technical fields.
Simple past (preterite), 'I designed'.
'I organize'. A common planning verb.
Simple past (preterite), 'I organized'. Note spelling change (z -> c).
'I plan'. A synonym for 'planificar'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I planned'.
'I save' (money, energy, time). The opposite of 'gastar'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I saved'.
'I spend' (money, time). The opposite of 'ahorrar'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I spent'.
Essential for any transaction: 'I pay'. Also used in '¿Puedo pagar?' (Can I pay?).
Simple past (preterite), 'I paid'. Note spelling change (g -> gu).
'I give as a gift'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I gave as a gift'.
'I celebrate'. A common social verb.
Simple past (preterite), 'I celebrated'.
'I decorate'. Common for holidays and home activities.
Simple past (preterite), 'I decorated'.
'I hang' (a picture, clothes) or 'I hang up' (the phone). A stem-changing verb (o -> ue).
Simple past (preterite), 'I hung'. Note spelling change (g -> gu).
'I keep', 'I put away', or 'I save' (a document).
Simple past (preterite), 'I kept'.
'I throw' or 'I throw away'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I threw away'.
'I recycle'. An important verb for daily life and environmental topics.
Simple past (preterite), 'I recycled'.
'I move' (an object). A stem-changing verb (o -> ue). Reflexive 'me muevo' means 'I move' (my body).
Simple past (preterite), 'I moved'.
'I lift'. The reflexive form 'me levanto' is more frequent and means 'I get up'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I lifted'.
Reflexive verb, 'I fall down'. Irregular 'yo' form.
Simple past (preterite), 'I fell down'.
'I stop'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I stopped'.
'I continue'. Note the accent mark on the 'u' in some forms.
Present progressive, 'I am continuing'.
'I interrupt'. A common conversational verb.
Simple past (preterite), 'I interrupted'.
'I avoid'. Used for people, places, and situations.
Simple past (preterite), 'I avoided'.
Dual meaning: 'I try' (food, clothes) or 'I test/prove'. A stem-changing verb (o -> ue).
Simple past (preterite), 'I tried'.
'I savor' or 'I taste'. More descriptive than 'probar'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I savored'.
'I smell'. An irregular verb; the 'h' is added in stem-changing forms (o -> ue -> hue).
Simple past (preterite), 'I smelled'.
'I cough'. A basic health-related verb.
Simple past (preterite), 'I coughed'.
'I sneeze'. Another basic health-related verb.
Simple past (preterite), 'I sneezed'.
'I breathe'. A fundamental biological action verb.
Present progressive, 'I am breathing'.
'I dream'. Used with 'con'. A stem-changing verb (o -> ue).
Simple past (preterite), 'I dreamed'.
Reflexive verb, 'I wake up'. A key daily routine verb and a stem-changer (e -> ie).
Simple past (preterite), 'I woke up'.
Reflexive verb, 'I relax'.
Present progressive, 'I am relaxing'.
Reflexive verb, 'I concentrate'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I concentrated'.
Reflexive verb, 'I get distracted'. Follows pattern of 'traer' with irregular 'yo' form.
Simple past (preterite), 'I got distracted'.
Reflexive verb, 'I make a mistake' or 'I am wrong'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I made a mistake'.
'I improve'. Can also be used to mean 'to get better' from an illness.
Simple past (preterite), 'I improved'.
'I worsen' or 'I get worse'. The opposite of 'mejorar'.
'It worsens'. Common for talking about situations like weather or health.
'I increase'.
'It increases'. Common in economic or descriptive contexts.
'It decreases'. The opposite of 'aumenta'.
'I decrease'.
'I adjust'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I adjusted'.
Reflexive verb, 'I adapt'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I adapted'.
Reflexive verb, 'I settle for' or 'I content myself with'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I settled for'.
'I convince'. Irregular 'yo' form (c -> z).
Simple past (preterite), 'I convinced'.
'I persuade'. A synonym for 'convencer'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I persuaded'.
'I support'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I supported'.
'I encourage' or 'I cheer on'.
A very common imperative phrase meaning 'Cheer up!'.
'I bother' or 'I annoy'.
'It bothers'. Used like 'gustar' to express annoyance: 'Me molesta que...'.
'I lend' or 'I loan'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I lent'.
'I return' (an object). A stem-changing verb (o -> ue).
Simple past (preterite), 'I returned'.
'I thank' or 'I appreciate'. Irregular 'yo' form (-zco verb).
Simple past (preterite), 'I thanked'.
'I congratulate'.
Simple past (preterite), 'I congratulated'.
